metadata.event_description: Detective puzzle 'Riddle of the Confederate Spy' by Moe Zilla

story.full_text:
Cannons fired in Maryland, as 45,000 Confederate soldiers crossed the Potomac River, 
approaching Washington, D.C. But far away in Illinois, a lonely Union sergeant performed his own duty – guarding a secluded stretch of railroad tracks against sabotage. It had only been one week, and already he missed home. That night, the sergeant’s troubled eyes searched the sky for answers, while the campfire cast shadows on the faces of four soldiers who accompanied him. “You're all good soldiers,” Sergeant Stoker said, fondly. “Unfortunately, one of you is a spy.” Then, the sergeant held up a bundle of dynamite. “This was on the bridge,” he said, his eyes searching the faces surrounding the campfire. “Without that bridge, the railroad can't continue on to Pennsylvania. Those Confederate soldiers attacking Maryland right now would like to stop our supplies from getting through. So much so, it seems, that they've snuck a saboteur into our unit.” The soldiers were far from the war's front lines, and yet such an integral part of the effort. A single bundle of dynamite could leave the troops ill-equipped and ineffective, changing the outcome of the crucial battles to come, and maybe even the war itself. The future of the United States was at stake. And now, an enemy spy was among them. A man they had worked with, talked with, and come to trust over the first week of guarding the railroad bridge. But how had the sergeant known? “There's no one else near this bridge for miles,” the sergeant said, wearily, “and no way to approach it without being seen. Unfortunately, I don't know any of you. Each of you arrived some time during this week, each saying you'd been sent here by your regiment's office.” He paced around the fire, “And, unfortunately – one of you is lying.” What was going through the sergeant's head? Why would he brandish the incriminating dynamite in front of every solider? Did he want to frighten the suspect, or was it a clever trick? Did the sergeant hope the spy would run away? Well, there was no such luck, and the situation quickly became dire. Could the soldiers sleep that night knowing one among them was an enemy? To determine the spy’s identity would take careful reflection and wit. “Each of you arrived here carrying a back pack,” he continued, “which could easily conceal a bundle of dynamite.” The men looked at each other uneasily. “Winslow,” the sergeant suddenly shouted, “Who's the President of the United States.” “Abraham Lincoln,” Winslow answered, suspiciously. “Were you hoping he'd say Jefferson Davis,” joked a soldier named Parker. “Then you'd know he was a Confederate rebel sticking dynamite under our bridge for sure!” “There are other ways,” said Sergeant Stoker. An owl hooted in the night. Sergeant Stoker scanned the four soldiers thoughtfully, and then finally asked, slowly, “Who arrived here first?” “I did,” said Parker, “followed by McMurty, then Winslow and finally Garret.” “I would've got here first,” insisted Garrett, “but my horse was lazy.” “Was your horse lazy, Garrett – or were you!” joked Parker. The soldiers laughed, relieved for a moment to break the tension. “And where is it that each of you is sleeping?” Stoker continued. “Under that tree,” said Garrett. “It blocks the sun when it comes up in the morning.” “In front of that bush,” answered Winslow, still suspicious. “Beside the campfire,” answered McMurty. “I'm always cold!” “Behind that rock,” said Parker. “So I can watch for Confederate spies!” “Refresh my memory,” said the sergeant casually, “What states were you sent here from?” “Ohio,” said Garrett. “I left just before harvest time came for our family's corn crop.” “So's he wouldn't have to work!” joked Parker. “I came from West Virginia where I log the incoming ships at a receiving house.” “Indiana,” said Winslow, very suspicious now. “I was working in my father's blacksmith shop.” “Illinois,” said McMurty. “I had an apprenticeship at a printer's shop.” “That settles it,” said Sergeant Stoker. He stood up from the campfire, and then returned, sternly carrying a pair of iron handcuffs. “I think I know which man should be wearing these.”

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. Fix the date.  
   • 45 000 Confederate troops crossing the Potomac and heading for Washington can only refer to Lee’s 1862 Maryland (Antietam) campaign.  
   • Therefore the scene takes place in September 1862.  

2. Look at the “states” the four men give.  
   • Illinois, Indiana and Ohio were already states of the Union in 1862.  
   • “West Virginia”, however, was not.  That part of Virginia did not break away from the Confederacy and enter the Union until 20 June 1863 – nine months after the date of our story.  
   • In 1862 no genuine Union soldier could possibly give “West Virginia” as his state of origin; he would have had to say “Virginia” (or “the western counties of Virginia”).  

3. Why did Sgt. Stoker ask the questions in exactly that order?  
   • He first made sure no one had left the camp (the sleeping-place question).  
   • Then he asked for the men’s home states, knowing the date and therefore knowing that one answer could not be genuine.  
   • As soon as he heard “West Virginia” he had all the proof he needed.  That is why he immediately said “That settles it” and reached for the hand-cuffs.  

4. Motive, opportunity, evidence.  
   • A Confederate agent would be eager to blow the bridge to stop Union rail traffic.  
   • All four men had physical opportunity, but only one has been caught in a clear, provable lie.  
   • The bundle of “dynamite” Stoker found shows a saboteur was present; Parker’s false statement shows which man the saboteur is.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Parker, Garrett, Winslow, McMurty
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Parker
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
Earlier that evening Parker slipped away from camp, carried the explosive and fixed it to a support of the railroad bridge.  
While making a routine inspection Sergeant Stoker discovered the charge and removed it before it could be detonated.  
Knowing that only one of his four new companions could have planted it, Stoker decided to question them in a way that would expose a false identity.  
Once Parker declared that he came from “West Virginia”, Stoker knew he had found his man: no authentic Union soldier in 1862 could have used the name of a state that did not yet exist.  
Stoker returned to camp, confronted the four, then placed Parker in irons to be taken for trial as a Confederate spy and saboteur.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
Garrett (Ohio), Winslow (Indiana) and McMurty (Illinois) gave answers wholly consistent with the year 1862; nothing in their statements contradicts fact, and Stoker had no evidence against them.  
Only Parker’s statement was historically impossible, and thus only Parker could be positively identified as the liar and the man who planted the explosive.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.reveal_text:
“I know it isn't McMurty,” said Sergeant Stoker. “If you had a pack full of hidden dynamite, you wouldn't be sleeping next to the campfire. … Even if you were cold.”
The soldiers all laughed and agreed that was true. McMurty was the most relieved of all, “But then who is the spy?” he asked
“Fact is … if I had a pack full of dynamite, I don't reckon I'd want to sleep in plain sight at all. Especially if I wanted to slip away some night and plant dynamite on the railroad bridge.” The men thought for a moment, as Sergeant Stoker continued his narrative. “I wouldn't sleep in front of a bush. And I wouldn't sleep out in the open under a tree. But behind a rock ...”
“Now wait a minute,” said Parker. But Sergeant Stoker smiled, and held up a finger to quiet him.
“It's mighty strange that you arrived in Illinois first,” Sergeant Stoker said to Parker. “… Since you said you were travelling the furthest – all the way from West Virginia.”
“I rode like the devil,” Parker insisted. “I didn't want to miss my chance to lend a hand!”
Sergeant Stoker nodded his head slowly, but then furrowed his brow. “I've only been stationed here for one week myself,” said Sergeant Stoker. “That doesn't seem like enough time for the West Virginia Army to send you on a 600-mile cross-country trip, all the way to Illinois.”
“They received a telegraph,” said Parker quickly. “And my horse travels fast!”
“85 miles a day?” asked Sergeant Stoker. “Even the best horses can't manage more than 50.”
Parker insisted his story was true, but Sergeant Stoker interrupted. “I believe you when you say that you logged the incoming ships at a receiving house. But I don't believe it was in West Virginia. … West Virginia doesn't touch the ocean.”
Parker looked around nervously at the faces of the other soldiers.
“You probably did work at a ship's receiving house,” the sergeant continued. “But Winfield Scott put a stop to that.” We all laughed. The Union's commanding general had enacted an “Anaconda” strategy, blocking all ships headed for the Confederacy. “I bet that left you with a lot of time on your hands. And a lot of reasons to want to put dynamite on our railroad bridge.”
“You can't be sure of this,” Parker shouted. “For all you know, you're about to arrest a loyal Union soldier.”
“I'm sure,” said Sergeant Stoker, “and here's why.”
“I never said the dynamite was under the bridge. I said it was on the bridge. But when you made your joke about Jefferson Davis, you said our rebel spy was sticking dynamite under our bridges. You're right, of course. But there's only one way you could've known where our spy was sticking his dynamite.”
Relief crossed Sergeant's Stoker's face, and for the first time that night, he smiled. “I'm sorry to spoil the campfire,” the sergeant said jovially. “Console yourself with the thought that someday, this war will be over, and we'll all be fellow country men again.”
“ … But until then – you're under arrest.”
